trans-unit.source: In <token>firstref_acs</token>, a <newTerm>service identity</newTerm> is a credential that is registered with an <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> and is intended for use by autonomous applications or clients.
trans-unit.target: In <token>firstref_acs</token>, a <newTerm>service identity</newTerm> is a credential that is registered with an <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> and is intended for use by autonomous applications or clients.

trans-unit.source: In other words, service identities are credentials that are configured globally for the <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> that allow applications or clients to authenticate directly with <token>secondref_acs</token> and receive a token.
trans-unit.target: In other words, service identities are credentials that are configured globally for the <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> that allow applications or clients to authenticate directly with <token>secondref_acs</token> and receive a token.

trans-unit.source: An <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> may contain many service identities.
trans-unit.target: An <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> may contain many service identities.

trans-unit.source: In <token>secondref_acs</token>, service identities are usually used for authenticating an autonomous application or client with an <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> and thereby grant that autonomous application or client access to the relying party application.
trans-unit.target: In <token>secondref_acs</token>, service identities are usually used for authenticating an autonomous application or client with an <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> and thereby grant that autonomous application or client access to the relying party application.

trans-unit.source: Rule groups that are associated with relying party applications exclusively define which service identities are accepted for which relying party applications.
trans-unit.target: Rule groups that are associated with relying party applications exclusively define which service identities are accepted for which relying party applications.

trans-unit.source: Service identities are not intended to be used as end-user credentials.
trans-unit.target: Service identities are not intended to be used as end-user credentials.

trans-unit.source: In <token>secondref_acs</token>, service identities are most commonly used in REST web service scenarios, over the OAuth WRAP protocol, where a client requests a SWT token directly from <token>secondref_acs</token> to present to the web service.
trans-unit.target: In <token>secondref_acs</token>, service identities are most commonly used in REST web service scenarios, over the OAuth WRAP protocol, where a client requests a SWT token directly from <token>secondref_acs</token> to present to the web service.

trans-unit.source: The following are the credential types that an <token>secondref_acs</token> service identity can be associated with:
trans-unit.target: The following are the credential types that an <token>secondref_acs</token> service identity can be associated with:

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Symmetric key</embeddedLabel>—This credential is used in signed SWT token requests to <token>secondref_acs</token> over the OAuth WRAP or the OAuth 2.0 protocols or in signed JWT token requests to <token>secondref_acs</token> over the OAuth 2.0 protocols.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Symmetric key</embeddedLabel>—This credential is used in signed SWT token requests to <token>secondref_acs</token> over the OAuth WRAP or the OAuth 2.0 protocols or in signed JWT token requests to <token>secondref_acs</token> over the OAuth 2.0 protocols.

trans-unit.source: In other words, this credential allows autonomous applications or clients to authenticate with <token>secondref_acs</token> by issuing a SWT or a JWT token and signing that SWT or JWT token with a symmetric key.
trans-unit.target: In other words, this credential allows autonomous applications or clients to authenticate with <token>secondref_acs</token> by issuing a SWT or a JWT token and signing that SWT or JWT token with a symmetric key.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Password</embeddedLabel>—This credential allows autonomous applications or clients to authenticate with <token>secondref_acs</token> by transmitting this credential to an <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Password</embeddedLabel>—This credential allows autonomous applications or clients to authenticate with <token>secondref_acs</token> by transmitting this credential to an <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>.

trans-unit.source: Password credentials are sent in plaintext token requests to <token>secondref_acs</token> over the OAuth WRAP or the OAuth 2.0, or the WS-Trust protocols.
trans-unit.target: Password credentials are sent in plaintext token requests to <token>secondref_acs</token> over the OAuth WRAP or the OAuth 2.0, or the WS-Trust protocols.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>X.509 Certificate</embeddedLabel>—An X.509 Certificate credential allows autonomous applications and clients to authenticate with <token>secondref_acs</token> via the WS-Trust protocol (certificate authentication).
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>X.509 Certificate</embeddedLabel>—An X.509 Certificate credential allows autonomous applications and clients to authenticate with <token>secondref_acs</token> via the WS-Trust protocol (certificate authentication).

trans-unit.source: For more information and detailed steps about how to add service identities with the credentials previously described using the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal, see <link xlink:href="8629f6a5-7463-4fe0-8ec5-66cc2c75a9aa" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">How To: Add Service Identities with X.509 Certificate, Password, or Symmetric Key</link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information and detailed steps about how to add service identities with the credentials previously described using the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal, see <link xlink:href="8629f6a5-7463-4fe0-8ec5-66cc2c75a9aa" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">How To: Add Service Identities with X.509 Certificate, Password, or Symmetric Key</link>.
